Welcome to the world of CLASSPATH ... One of the less elegant aspects of Ja=
va development.

The issue that you are dealing with here is that there are=
 two kinds of references that you can have in a CLASSPATH. The first is a J=
AR file and the second is a directory. Unfortunately, a JAR file in a direc=
tory on the CLASSPATH does not get searched (I know, I know, it's silly, bu=
t we have to live with it). So to address your question, you will need to i=
nclude both the reference to the Junit JAR file and the directory where the=
 samples live. eg:

CLASSPATH=3D$CLASSPATH:/Applications/Utilities/Java/jun=
it3.8.1/junit.jar:/Applications/Utilities/Java/junit3.8.1
export CLASSPATH
=

This will get you to the next step, but it does sound like you need to lea=
rn a little more about the shell, (http://www.tldp.org/LDP/abs/html/ is a g=
ood programming guide to the bash shell).

Also, I strongly suggest switchi=
ng to ant (http://ant.apache.org/) for your compile/build process. It isn't=
 perfect, but it does 99% of most everything that I need, and I code in Jav=
a for a living. It will also help with CLASSPATH issues.

Consider switchin=
g to a CLASSPATH of ".", yes that is just the current directory and then us=
ing the <path> facilities for individual projects.

Anyway, this might have=
 been more than you wanted, but I hope that something in the above helps.

=
Feel free to contact me directly if you want more help, or we can continue =
to work through the mailing list so that others can be helped. :-)

Simon

=
